School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Dialogues in STEM
Description: The questions addressed by those within the STEM disciplines are increasingly complex, requiring collaboration, effective communication, and careful attention to social and ethical factors. In this seminar, STEM students will consider practices that promote work in interdisciplinary teams and strategies for conveying ideas across a wide variety of audiences. Students will also consider the benefits of cross-disciplinary engagement with experts outside of the STEM disciplines.

Name: May Study Abroad
Description: Students will explore a French-speaking city, region, or country for two to four weeks as part of an immersion experience that will involve a homestay and intensive language study. Locations will alternate each year between France (Paris and Marseille) and Quebec (Montreal and Quebec City) or another destination.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Leadership in Kenya
Description: This course focuses on how leaders in Kenya and East Africa develop businesses, provide health care, organize government and education, respond to crises, address poverty and issues of justice, promote community development and micro-finance, and conduct worship. Students hear lectures from Kenyan leaders and travel to site locations to see leadership in action. Students examine leadership and culture in both urban and rural areas, with an eye to the leadership and partnership role Americans may have in East Africa. Students will be required to read selected materials before departure, report on and lead discussions on them, take quizzes, write reflection papers, and journal daily.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Inclusive Teaching: Ability, Language, and Multicultural Education
Description: This course provides insight into learners with diverse ability and linguistic background. It includes study of the role of culture in language development and academic achievement; second language development theories for classroom organization and pedagogy; characteristics of students with identified disability; and the history of special education, individualized planning, and pedagogy. A Christian view of persons is developed to counteract deficit thinking, recognize the gifts of all students, and identify human and linguistic difference as asset. Twelve hours will be spent outside of class in observation of K-12 school programs.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Electrocardiography in Exercise Science
Description: In this course, students will learn the relationships between cardiac anatomic structure, cardiac physiology, cardiac cycle, and electrocardiogram tracings. Students will learn a five-step systemic approach to reading and interpreting an electrocardiogram by assessing an electrocardiogram for rate, rhythm, axis, hypertrophy, and infarction. Finally, students will learn to provide concluding comments about an electrocardiogram, as determined by the five-step approach.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Principles of Auditing
Description: An introduction of practices and procedures of assurance services, including planning, assessing risk, testing controls, and obtaining and documenting evidence in accordance with authoritative standards including the AICPA Statements on Auditing Standards. Name: Animal Behavior Lab
Description: Laboratory and field activities will focus on real-world assessment of animal behavior. Specific focus will be given to developing familiarity with field techniques used in public health entomology and acarology.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Wildlife Biology and Conservation Lab
Description: Through field trips, students will learn to identify game and non-game animals, with special attention given to the identification of vertebrate animals in the Great Lakes region. Students will also develop proficiencies in ecological research and inventory methods used in habitat, population, and community assessment of vertebrates, particularly as they pertain to contemporary conservation and management issues. Students will also work in groups to complete a research project focused on evaluating aspects of animal ecology, wildlife management, and/or human-wildlife interactions.

Name: Plant Taxonomy Lab
Description: Students will engage in a series on hands-on activities that will promote the learning of botanical terminology associated with leaves, stems, flowers, fruits, as well as major plant groups including gymnosperms, wind-pollinated monocots, and tropical plants. Laboratory time will also be dedicated to a class project that will include field identification, use of botanical keys, and a floristic quality assessment (FQA). Through these various experiences, the students will develop technical skills, practical field approaches, and data analysis strategies that are typically used by the professional botanical community.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Foundations of Public Service
Description: An introduction to the legal and ethical foundations of public service and its historical and organizational expressions, engaging perennial debates over the interplay among government, for-profit, and non-profit sectors. School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Economic and Community Development
Description: An introduction to the academic literature on community development and impediments that stand in its way (i.e., economic divestment, inadequate housing, structural violence, lack of community services, crime, etc.). It considers the various roles that government, the private sector, and nonprofit organizations play in community revitalization and offers models of change for community revitalization that include, among others, doughnut economics, social mobilization, and asset-based community development.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Local Politics and Government
Description: An introduction to local politics and government in the United States, examining who is involved in local politics and how political processes and state and federal regulations shape policies. Topics include urban political institutions, machine politics, federal urban policy, race representation in cities, local elections, structure of local administrations and key policy areas within the local and metropolitan context, such as education, policing, and urban planning and development. The course will also examine the historical practices of cities with the United States.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: FYRES Lab
Description: This laboratory course engages students in hands-on dune research experiences, with many activities taking place at Lake Michigan dune sites. Student activities are supported by upper-level student research mentors. Directed experiences at dune sites early in the semester give students experience in dune environments, dune research methods, data analysis, and the process of scientific inquiry. Then teams of students implement investigations focused on Michigan dunes, including designing their study, collecting field data, analyzing the results, and drawing conclusions. Each team communicates their study results in a conference-style research poster and oral presentation at the end of the semester.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Oceanography Lab
Description: An introductory oceanography lab course that covers the interpretation and use of seafloor maps, analysis of plate tectonics process and how they contribute to seafloor formation, features, and processes; observations, measurements, and interpretation of seawater and atmospheric data; the recognition and interpretation of climate variability and El Nino; the classification of marine organisms by taxonomy, ecological niche, and feeding. This course has required field trips.

Name: Coastal Geomorphology Methods
Description: This course gives students hands-on experience with methods for investigating coastal geomorphology. Students will collect field data at coastal sites, analyse collected samples with lab equipment, model coastal processes in lab simulations, work with online datasets, and do computer analysis of data. There will be several field trips outside of class time during the semester. Students must be concurrently enrolled in [[permalink=470|tooltip:{'title':1}]]%prefix% %code%[[/permalink]], because that course provides background knowledge for understanding methods and interpreting results.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Introduction to Biological Psychology
Description: This course provides an introduction to the structure and function of the nervous system and the ways in which cognitive, behavioral, and emotional functioning are supported by brain function. Topics will include a basic introduction to the neuron and neurotransmitters as well as supporting cells in the central nervous system, the peripheral nervous system, functions of the main brain areas, and symptoms that emerge with brain injury to specific areas, and an introduction to the biological basis of vision, memory, language, executive functioning, and mood regulation. Additionally, application of faith integration themes to the topics of neuroscience will be integrated throughout the course.

Name: Exploratory Data Science and Analytics
Description: An introduction to data science and analytics, including the management of data from multiple, heterogeneous sources typically found in a corporate environment. Students will gain an understanding of how to manage and analyze large volumes of data using data modeling and visualization software tools. Students also investigate the ethical considerations of data availability and analysis along with career options in the fields of data science and analytics. Not open to those who have completed [[permalink=580|tooltip:{'title':1}]]%prefix% %code%[[/permalink]].

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Introduction to Plant Physiology
Description: An exploration of the physiological function of plants that builds upon ecological and cellular biology concepts and lays a foundation for more advanced studies in the upper-level biology courses. The course will focus on angiosperms and gymnosperms, seeking to inform students of basic plant morphology and anatomy (structure) that leads to understanding of growth requirements and physiological processes of plants (function). Understanding the processes by which plants grow and develop connects students to topics such as ecosystem function, physical transfer of solar to chemical energy, nutrition and human health.

Name: Human Anatomy Lab

Students study the human skeleton in detail and dissect a representative mammal to explore other organ systems. Students gain hands-on experience dissecting biological tissues and develop proficiency in the proper use of anatomical language.

Name: Human Physiology Lab
Description: Students use established laboratory methods to investigate basic physiological techniques in an investigative setting.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Medical Microbiology Lab
Description: Students practice essential microbiological techniques such as sterile technique, simple and Gram staining, oil-immersion microscopy and both liquid and solid media cultivation methods. An emphasis is placed on choosing selective and differential media to isolate and identify specific microorganisms such as coliforms and Staphylococci/Streptococci. Biochemical testing of bacterial isolates is also emphasized, with students choosing a "pet" and then characterizing its physical appearance and metabolic capability. Culmination of the lab includes identification of unknown bacteria using student-generated dichotomous keys, and previously recorded physiological and metabolic data.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: 18th- and 19th-Century European Art
Description: ARTH 133 introduces some of the most notable paintings, prints, and decorative arts produced in Europe from 1700 to 1900. The rise of new public audiences for art, alongside traditional court structures, is a central concern. Gender and the status of women artists are also important themes.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Japanese Art History
Description: This course provides an introduction to the visual arts of Japan. The course focuses on the production of pictures, objects, gardens, and buildings in Japan, with an emphasis on aesthetic categories and sensibilities. The course ends with an extended exploration of contemporary Japanese art.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: American Environmentalism
Description: This course traces the development of American environmentalism in the late 19th and 20th centuries. It begins with dramatic transformation of the American landscape in the 19th century. After tracing early efforts to protect forests and scenery in the Progressive Era, the course explores the environmental movement in the post-war era and development of modern environmental law. While focusing on the dominant environmental movement, the course highlights marginalized environmental movements, such as the environmental justice movement. The course ends with a critical discussion of the contemporary sustainability movement.

Name: Paleontology Lab
Description: Students learn from close observation, examination, and drawing many fossil specimens over the semester. Labs focus on the characteristics of approximately 20 phyla of macroscopic plants and animals, as well as others that are traditionally classified as "microfossils." School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Democracy in America: State and Local Government
Description: This course examines state and local government in the United States, including institutions and politics of state, county, and municipal government and their variety across the United States. Students will learn about the roles of different levels of government and consider prominent theories on governance and community development with an eye toward reforming systems and building integrated communities.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Particles, Nuclei, and Astronomy
Description: This course provides and overview of astronomy and particle physics, and surveys key historical developments in physics as well as foundational scientific methods and assumptions. Topics in astronomy include: observational astronomy; motion of stars and planets; geocentric and heliocentric models of the solar system; Galileo, Kepler, and Newton. Topics in atomic and particle physics include: the wave-particle duality of light; atomic nuclei, nuclear reactions and radiation; quarks and the Standard Model of particle physics.

Name: Artificial Intelligence
Description: An introduction to artificial intelligence. Topics include problem solving, knowledge representation, planning, machine learning, natural language processing, and robotics. Students will be introduced to programming techniques from AI such as heuristic search, expert systems, and neural networks, as well as to AI's philosophical, psychological, and religious context.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Advanced German Culture II
Description: This course offers a study of various eras and cultural themes of German-speaking Europe and does so at a more advanced level than in the prerequisite courses. Students encounter authentic material such as text (in a variety of genres), film, and various audio and visual media ranging from literature to the visual and audial arts. Attention is paid to visual and rhetorical culture, and students gain valuable experience reading, observing, or even performing and interpreting cultural artifacts. Attention is also paid to the implicit worldviews, assumptions, and goals of the texts and artifacts. This course will also pay attention to advanced grammar and give practice in certain genres of writing.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: The Social Context of Education
Description: This course guides students in an examination of the social context of schooling, including the interaction and impact of social structures and systems on the educational experiences of individuals and groups.?Particular attention is given to the study of race, class, and gender and how social science helps us understand their impact on schools, society, and learners. A biblically-guided understanding of justice helps shape this critical analysis.?This course includes a 12-hour project involving field work and centered on schools, communities, and families.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Teaching and Learning Lab
Description: Students will actively explore the core knowledge, practices and dispositions of teaching and learning through examination of model teaching, enactment of practice teaching in small groups, and reflective discussion. The course will focus on what it means to live out Christian faith commitments and practices in a variety of settings. This includes consideration of who teaches and is taught, what is taught, how and in what context we teach, and the complex ways in which these ideas interact and compete in PK-12 classrooms.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Internship I
Description: This internship provides field-based learning through a part-time placement in a grade 5-12 classroom. With the supervision of a faculty member and a master teacher, interns develop their understanding and performance of the knowledge, skills and dispositions expected of 5th- to 12th-grade educators. Individual observations, mentoring, and coursework aide interns in developing as professionals. Varied frameworks and tools are used throughout the internship to assess readiness for the professional field. A grade of C or higher along with the recommendation of the course instructor are required to continue in the education program.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Extending and Deepening Literacy Instruction: Internship I
Description: Candidates learn how to teach engaging literacy lessons and design instructional strategies that support students in becoming skillful and engaged readers and writers across subject areas. Candidates further develop their understanding of creating equitable classroom cultures; their capacity to design literacy programs that reflect their knowledge of curriculum, assessment, and instruction; and their knowledge, skill, and commitment to equitable and justice-oriented practices.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Introduction to Cognitive Impairment: Birth through School Age
Description: A comprehensive study of the characteristics of infants and children who have cognitive impairment, intellectual or developmental disability, or developmental delay. Common causes, medical and school-based definitional issues, assessment, eligibility for special education, and interventions will be discussed. While special attention is given to supports for children with cognitive impairment as learners, the course examines functioning across a variety of settings besides the school, such as the church, home, and neighborhood. A Christian view of persons, community, and discipleship, along with the concepts of inclusion, social role valorization, and self-determination are integrating elements in the course. Seven hours of observation in a local school or early childhood program is required for this course.

Historical and contemporary perspectives on intellectual disability will be explored, as will common causes, definitional issues, and interventions. Seven hours of observation in a transition or adult services program is required for this course.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Teaching Social Studies in Elementary Grades: Internship I
Description: Students consider social studies content and pedagogy for children from Pre-K through grade 6. Knowledge development will focus primarily on the political and economic threads of the social studies. The inquiry process and other social studies instructional strategies will be developed with an emphasis on finding quality sources (including children's and adolescent literature) for children's exploration of social studies content and issues in the social studies. Through classroom peer teaching and a practicum, participants further develop and demonstrate core teaching practices in their practicum settings.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Student Teaching Seminar
Description: Taking an interdisciplinary perspective, students will consider the question, "What contributes to flourishing in learning communities?," particularly when faced with a contemporary challenge. Pulling from experiences in their full-time internship in a P-12 classroom, previous program coursework, research, and personal inquiries, students will select a challenge that transpires in their assigned placement. They will consider how self, context and the core aspects of teaching (pedagogy, curriculum, assessment, and classroom management) along with a Reformed Christian worldview inform their response and engage practice in ways that foster greater flourishing for all.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: The Christian Teacher
Description: This course will examine multiple frameworks for understanding how Christian commitments can inform teacher identity and formation and guide professional practice. The course will include attention to how the Bible, with its diversity of genres, functions as an educational text, as well as to exemplars of Christian engagement with education and key facets of teacher and student vocation. A range of faith-informed practices will be examined as they apply to professional practice in educational settings.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Teaching Science in Middle School
Description: A consideration of the methods, pedagogies, and strategies associated with teaching science in middle school. Curricular resources for teaching science, including the use of technology and written materials, are also examined with consideration of the criteria for their evaluation. Additional topics include assessment, benchmarks and standards, and lesson and unit development. The relationship of Christian faith to the teaching of science in the classroom is also examined. Field experiences during normal course hours are included.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Science and Engineering Practices
Description: This course targets scientific and engineering practices and skills foundational to scientific and engineering literacy. Content covered includes the role of models in science, forces and the particulate nature of matter, scientific testing, and engineering practices. Special attention is given to developing a theological understanding of how God works in nature and how creation manifests God's grandeur.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Organic Chemistry for Educators
Description: This survey course is specifically for the preparation of high school (7-12) science teachers as well as those who opt to specialize in chemistry education. The fundamental concepts of organic chemistry and biochemistry are presented with an emphasis on the chemical nature of biological systems. Topics such as structure, functional groups, and chemical reactivity are illustrated using common organic molecules, including enzymes, buffers, and cellular energy metabolism.

School/College Name: Global Campus
Name: Servant Leadership and Transformation
Description: This course will provide students with an overview and awareness of the social, cognitive, and psychological processes characterizing authentic and servant leadership. Focus will be on providing students the critical skills of self-leadership towards personal and professional goals as the context for studying service, influence, and intentional development and growth. Students will learn about individual differences and about themselves using assessments, analytical tools, and theory to develop action plans that will support sustained growth towards personal objectives. Students will also learn through multiple case studies of authentic and servant leadership.

School/College Name: Global Campus
Name: Career Exploration
Description: This course is designed to help adult students explore their career interests, professional goals, and vocational trajectory. Throughout this course students will discover the skills, competencies, dispositions necessary for success in their career field. They will be invited to explore ethical frameworks that can be applied in their professional lives. Through completion of assessments, personal reflection, individual research, and interaction with the Career Center, students will become familiar with their unique strengths and the current hiring environment in their field of study to prepare themselves to be competitive for employment opportunities.

School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Understanding Institutional Racism and Racial Internalization
Description: This class builds upon the concepts learned in [[permalink=1234|tooltip:{'title':1}]]%prefix% %code%[[/permalink]] with the John M. Perkins Leadership Fellows. The students will deepen their understanding of institutional, cultural and internalized racism, the church's role and the way it persists today. Further, students will explore ways to dismantle institutional racism in working toward the Beloved Community and Shalom. They will also be invited to engage in the redemptive practice of caucusing to address misshapen internalized racial identities.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Project Management
Description: Students are introduced to key project management concepts and competencies, including the fundamentals of project management encompassed in the Project Management Institute's (PMI's) Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK); Lean/Agile methodologies; and design thinking.  Application of knowledge and development of skills and abilities are honed through case studies and simulations. Conceptual coverage is intended to contribute to students' preparation to sit for the PMI Certified Associate in Project Management (PMI-CAPM) exam.

Name: Communication with Dashboards and Stories
Description: Student knowledge about data preparation and visualization is extended by gaining hands-on expertise with workflow software and designing dashboards and stories to explain observations of data research. Students will work through given scenarios to apply the concepts as well as providing explanations and recommendations complemented with written and oral communication. Tableau coverage will prepare the student to take the Tableau Desktop Specialist Certification.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Business Enterprise Systems
Description: Students gain insight into common enterprise structures that support corporate information needs. After an introduction to general systems theory and the definition of an Information System, the course explores the foundational building blocks of information technology, such as networking, data repository options (relational databases, etc.), cloud resources, and data collection technology (e.g., RFID, IOT). Students will gain hands-on experience with an open-source Enterprise Resource Planning package and its subcomponents, such as Customer Relationship Management, Human Resources, and Manufacturing Requirements Planning. The course considers interorganizational systems such as EDI, blockchain, and associated standards. Students will be introduced to the implications of shalom in technology ethics, as pertaining to privacy, honesty, and consent.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Business Analytics Management
Description: This course looks at implementing and applying analytics through corporate governance, systems analysis, and decision-making models. After an introduction to enterprise architectures, students will learn how to facilitate discussions and activities to analyze existing business plans, decision methodologies, and processes to reveal sources of data for knowledge mining. Each student will experience a leadership role by facilitating a case study involving business value through analytics. Students will further explore the implications of shalom in technology ethics, as pertaining to artificial intelligence, and technology as an expression of the values of its creators

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Data Wrangling
Description: An introduction to collecting, managing, and processing large data sets. This course focuses on the core skills and concepts needed to pull data from a range of sources both inside and outside of organizations; to filter, transform, and combine data sets in preparation for data cleaning and analysis; and to construct quantitative summaries and basic visualizations.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Introduction to Machine Learning
Description: Organizations leverage increasingly large collections of data about people, products, and processes. Machine learning provides tools to discover patterns and anticipate trends in such data. This course introduces the foundational principles of machine learning and provides a survey of a wide range of predictive methods, both battle-tested classics and emerging high-capacity deep learning models.

Name: Visualizing Data and Models
Description: An introduction to the principles and practices of effective data visualization as an essential skill for learning from data and for communicating with others, both within and outside of an organization. Students will combine principles from statistics, psychology, and computer science to design and create visualizations and use them to communicate with and about data to stakeholders and others.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Ethics for Data Science
Description: An introduction to ethical frameworks and their applications in the context of data science. This course will help students reflect on the moral dimensions of the practice of data science in relation to what we believe, what we do, and what sorts of people we want to be. Ethical issues such as fairness, privacy, justice, transparency, and why we should try to be morally good will be considered both theoretically and practically (by applying them to issues that arise in the practice of data science and in contemporary social life more generally). Students will reflect on both historical and contemporary sources and consider what difference Christian faith makes to the theory and the practice of morality.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Applied Regression
Description: This course takes a practical approach to the fitting, assessment, interpretation, and presentation of statistical models, introducing students to a broad range of applied regression methods via case studies with real datasets. Topics include data preparation and visualization, the generalized linear model framework, and specific examples of frequently used models (such as multiple regression, regression for count and binary data, generalized additive models, and models to account for hierarchical structure or dependence).

Name: Business Analytics Project
Description: Student teams apply their knowledge in a data project to support a business (profit or nonprofit). The team will work through the full analytics cycle to identify a goal, gather and analyze data, visualize findings, and provide the business with either a tool or a recommendation at the end of the project. Students will regularly reflect on the application of their faith as they nurture their relationships with clients.

Name: Introduction to Deep Learning
Description: An introduction to the use and implementation of neural network (deep learning) models. Students will select machine learning algorithms appropriate to a given task. Applications may include text classification, image classification, and price prediction.

Name: Project in Data Science I
Description: This is the first course in a two-course sequence in which students will complete a masters-level data science project. This project experience will give students the opportunity to apply concepts and techniques learned in several masters courses by developing a significant data application. The work will include necessary library research, design and prototyping, implementation, analysis, and deployment. Name: Entrepreneurship Practicum 1
Description: Students who have a business or an idea for a business pursue their venture under the guidance of a mentor learning the essentials of developing and validating their business idea. Students will gain insights into their personality and develop project management skills to strengthen their entrepreneurial effectiveness.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Design Thinking
Description: Design Thinking is about learning processes and techniques to generate valuable insights into the needs of users, the environment and society as a whole and to use those insights to develop ideas and a variety of ways to better meet those needs through innovative products, services and programs that seek to make things better. Research techniques such as observation, interviewing and immersive empathy along with methods to prototype, test and quickly iterate ideas will be covered. The ethics of the design research techniques and the human-centered design approaches will also be explored.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Advanced Human Physiology and Pathophysiology
Description: Physiology is the study of normal body function and pathophysiology is the study of how a body's function changes when disease occurs. Students in this course will be introduced to the biochemical or cellular mechanisms by which the human body normally functions, the structural and functional changes that occur in diseased states, and the impact of these changes on overall health. Normal function and diseases of the cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, hormonal, muscular, neural, renal, reproductive, and respiratory systems will be investigated using a classic organ system approach and case studies. Current research literature will be emphasized.

Normal function and diseases of the cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, hormonal, muscular, neural, renal, reproductive, and respiratory systems will be investigated using a classic organ system approach and case studies. Current research literature will be emphasized.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Dutch Sustainability: Is Orange the New Green?
Description: When faced with sustainability challenges, the Dutch have always innovated their way toward a more stable and resilient environment. Through orienting reading assignments and field excursions, students learn about this country's richly varied history of cultural inclusion, land reclamation, water management, energy production, food production, and environmental preservation. These innovations have shaped Dutch society and culture in ways that earn their distinction as global leaders in redesigning their economic and infrastructure systems to meet today's sustainability challenges. Online excursion guides prepare students for visits to places throughout the Netherlands that feature old and new innovations, places of historic and cultural significance, and conversations with local experts. Course assessment is based on reflective assignments and class discussions. Students can expect to learn some Dutch in this course, but knowing Dutch is not required, since many people in the Netherlands speak some English.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Global Supply Chain Practicum 2
Description: The Global Supply Chain Practicum is an international travel course required for students pursuing the OSCM major. This course is offered during the January term and will focus on the impact of operations and global supply chain decisions in the context of local flourishing and economic impact. This course involves engagement with key technical aspects of manufacturing and operations management but also allows students to engage with reflective readings and writing considering the impact of economic opportunity, development and ethical leadership primarily focused on economic deserts. SCM 311 is an off-campus course. Note: Students must take both [[permalink=1050|tooltip:{'title':1}]]%prefix% %code%[[/permalink]] and SCM 311 in consecutive terms.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Curriculum, Instruction, and Content Area Literacy
Description: Students will examine the nature and function of literacy in the secondary content curriculum. Specifically, this course will examine the reading and writing skills and practices that support the ways of knowing and doing characteristic of secondary school subject areas. All of these areas will be examined through the lens of a reformed Christian perspective. An extensive practicum ([[permalink=1297|tooltip:{'title':1}]]%prefix% %code%[[/permalink]]) will assist students in linking theory and practice in a classroom setting. Students will complete a project tailored to their disciplinary interests.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Internship I
Description: This internship provides field-based learning through a part-time placement in a grade 6-12 classroom. With the supervision of a faculty member and a master teacher, interns develop their understanding and performance of the knowledge, skills, and dispositions expected of 6th- to 12th-grade educators. Individual observations, mentoring, and coursework aide interns in developing as professionals. Varied frameworks and tools are used throughout the internship to assess readiness for the professional field. Students will complete a project tailored to their disciplinary interests.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Student Teaching Seminar
Description: Taking an interdisciplinary perspective, students will consider the question, "What contributes to flourishing in learning communities?," particularly when faced with a contemporary challenge. Pulling from experiences in their full-time internship in a P-12 classroom, previous program coursework, research, and personal inquiries, students will select a challenge that transpires in their assigned placement. They will consider how self, context and the core aspects of teaching (pedagogy, curriculum, assessment, and classroom management) along with a Reformed Christian worldview inform their response and engage practice in ways that foster greater flourishing for all. Students will also complete a project tailored to their disciplinary pedagogy interests.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Chemistry, Policy, and the Future of Our Planet
Description: Students interested in public health, public policy, or advocacy work should know the science behind chemical advances and natural phenomena so that they can make decisions that promote the sustainable flourishing of the planet. This course will provide students with chemical principles related to direct application of chemistry to the environment (pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers) as well as additional applications including drinking water, climate change, energy sources (combustion, solar, nuclear), batteries, and consumer products. Students will learn about past, current, and possible government policies (federal, state, local) that can be used to regulate and incentivize chemistry for flourishing.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Culinary Medicine
Description: Culinary medicine is an evidence-based field that combines nutrition and culinary knowledge in maintaining health and preventative care. This course will examine several common diets and the associated health benefits, and focus on the whole food, plant-based diet that is an ideal diet for both human and planetary health. Students will learn about dietary behavior changes and food chemistry as well as practice cooking skills that lead to a healthier diet. Through this course, students will see how food and cooking can be incorporated into healthcare and community goals.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Faith and Pedagogy
Description: This course will examine how Christian commitments can inform pedagogical designs and processes, and not merely course content or teacher identity. Name: Honors Biology

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Philosophical Explorations
Description: A brief introduction to fundamental questions about the good life and how to make our lives meaningful. The course addresses such issues as what justifies our beliefs and what responsibilities we have to others. An emphasis is placed on philosophical reflection and discussion, constructing and evaluating arguments, reading and interpreting philosophical texts, writing clear expository prose, and engaging in faith-oriented and faith-based inquiry. The course aims to help students use philosophy to respond to central issues facing contemporary society.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: AI and You: Sex, Care, and War in an Age of Intelligent Bots
Description: In this course students will study the quickly advancing field of artificial intelligence, analyzing the promises and pitfalls of such technologies as care bots, sex bots, lethal autonomous weapons systems, ChatGPT, etc., and their impact on our personal and communal understanding of what it means to be human, as well as their impact on social and moral development. The framework for exploration will be a philosophical and Christian vision of what it is to be human and what it looks like to live a flourishing human life. We will read Sex, Tech and Faith, by Kate Ott, as well as a variety of AI-related articles. To help students integrate what they learn with their own uses of and interfaces with AI systems, students will write a series of (non-ChatGPT generated) self-reflective, self-interrogative papers concerning AI and themselves.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Augustine's Confessions: A Map of the Heart
Description: An exploration of Augustine's Confessions as the itinerary of the self on a quest for authenticity. Introduces to fundamental questions in philosophy about knowledge, reality, and the good life. Themes include the nature of the human person, the centrality of love, the existence of God, the problem of evil, the essence of friendship, and more. Situates Augustine relationship to the history of philosophy, the Reformed tradition, and contemporary thought.

Name: Glittering Vices: The Capital Vices and Christian Character
Description: In this course students will study the seven deadly sins (capital vices), analyzing each vice and its impact on individual character development and communal culture. The framework for this study will be the Christian virtue tradition and its project of personal transformation (spiritual formation). The class will use Glittering Vices as the primary text, with supplemental material from Aristotle, Augustine, Thomas Aquinas, contemporary virtue ethics, and Christian spiritual formation literature. To integrate what they learn, students will participate in practices of self-examination and virtue and reflect on those practices.

Name: Sustainability Experience
Description: Sustainability Experience involves a minimum of 100 hours per semester (or equivalent) in a professional setting with an approved sustainability-themed project in a research, business, or nonprofit organization. Academic work includes class meetings and in-person and online discussions, an assessment from the employer-supervisor, readings, seminars/workshops, reflective journals, and participation in the sustainability showcase. Primarily for students pursuing the [[permalink=1541|new:{'title':1}]]sustainability designation[[/permalink]].

School/College Name: Global Campus
Name: Career Readiness in Community
Description: This course is designed for students interested in a structured approach to developing career readiness skills alongside a community of peers, whether they are headed for the work world or graduate school upon graduation. Utilizing classroom discussions, activities, readings, and Calvin LifeWork modules, students will finish the course with a stronger understanding of the concept of vocation, an increased ability to articulate their strengths and experiences to potential employers and grad schools and equipped to bridge the gap between classroom learning and application in industry. Course content is applicable to all majors.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Foundations of Global Health
Description: The world continues to become more interconnected, providing opportunities for both the spread of disease but also collective problem solving. This course sets the foundation for understanding how globalization affects population health across the world, introduces how we quantify the global burden of disease, identifies the global actors responsible for setting health policies and their roles, and provides a context for health and human rights. Students will identify key global health issues and needs, such as infant and maternal health, infectious diseases, and nutrition, as well as determinants of health in these areas. Crosslisted as [[permalink=829|tooltip:{'title':1}]]%prefix% %code%[[/permalink]].

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Evidence-Based Nursing Scholarship
Description: This course focuses on the use of evidenced-based practice principles for nursing scholarship and the use of research in practice to improve health and healthcare outcomes. The process of application, translation, and implementation of best evidence to guide clinical decision making will be the focus of the class. The unique role of the nurse-patient relationship, patient preference, and clinical expertise will be the lens through which evidence-based nursing scholarship is based.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Advanced Clinical Pathophysiology across the Lifespan
Description: The focus of this course is the application of advanced pathophysiologic concepts for frequently encountered conditions in clinical practice. It provides an in-depth analysis of epidemiology, risk factors, etiology, pathophysiology, clinical manifestations, and laboratory tests for select acute and chronic illnesses across the lifespan in the lens of the Reformed Christian worldview.

Name: Advanced Clinical Pharmacology across the Lifespan

Evidenced based practices will be utilized to select individualized patient treatment plans.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Clinical Health Promotion and Population Health
Description: This course explores theories of health promotion and disease prevention, including individual- and population-oriented preventive interventions at the advanced practice level. The course will include in-depth analyses of relevance of patient education, interprofessional teams, epidemiology, health beliefs, social determinants of health, and other factors associated with health promotion in population-based care. Students will be provided with tools to design and deliver evidence-based, culturally relevant, clinical prevention interventions among various populations across the lifespan. Competency in assessing efficiacy of a system's capacity to serve a target sub-poplulation's health care needs will be addressed.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Advanced Physical Assessment and Holistic Health Care
Description: In this course, students learn advanced health history and physical examination skills across the lifespan. Emphasis is on interview, communication, and psychomotor skill development, with an end goal of facilitating diagnoses of illness and disease. It also includes concepts related to health assessment, which supports the basic tenets of health promotion and disease prevention and includes concepts of holistic care.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Quality Improvements and Informatics
Description: This course focuses on quality improvement processes and use of information technology within health care systems for advanced practice nursing. This assists in driving the provision of care, data collection, decision-making, communication, and knowledge expansion. In this course, students use quality improvement tools and information and technologies to drive quality-improvement strategies that benefit diverse populations across the healthcare system.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Interprofessional Collaboration, Health Policy, and Advocacy
Description: The healthcare environment is ever-changing with significant health disparities associated with systemic challenges and social determinants of health. This course will focus on the importance of interprofessional collaboration in delivering holistic care to promote the health of individuals and families. The course will prepare students to effectively apply theories and models of policy-making to promote population health. Students will need to understand the context in which they are practicing and make the linkages among policy, financing, and access to quality health care. The course will include in-depth analyses of the influences of governmental policies on vulnerable populations and the complexity of financing the US healthcare delivery system to deliver safe, equitable, and ethical care. The role of the advanced practice nurse as an advocate and effective group leader or team member in health politics for the workplace, organization, government, and community will be presented.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Practicum in Nursing Education
Description: This course requires integration of nurse educator skills into a practicum setting. The course may be taken as variable credit, but four credit hours are required (300 clock hours). The focus is on teaching and clinical practice in both a nurse academic setting and a clinical nursing education setting supervised by a preceptor expert. Logs of clock hours, practicum experiences, and teaching plans will be created and submitted to practicum instructor for feedback on a regular basis. The National League for Nursing (NLN) Nurse Educator competencies will serve as basis for practicum evaluation.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Clinical Nurse Leader Role
Description: This course will study the specific clinical nurse leader roles and responsibilities for providing clinical leadership for patient care practices and delivery, including the design, coordination, and evaluation of care for individuals, families, groups, and populations. The focus is to integrate patient data and apply evidenced-based strategies for managing acute and chronic illnesses for the best patient outcome. Students are expected to participate in identification and measurement of care outcomes and be accountable for evaluation and improvement of patients at the point of care. This includes risk anticipation, lateral integration of care for patients, team leadership and collaboration with other health professionals, use of information systems and technologies, and stewardship and leveraging of resources to advocate for patient.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Clinical Nurse Specialist Practicum I
Description: This course involves 300 hours of integration of clinical nurse specialist skills into a practicum setting anyplace within the continuum of care within any healthcare setting. The focus is for students to integrate their knowledge from the three spheres of care (patient, consultation, system). Students are expected to apply theoretical knowledge gained from the Clinical Nurse Specialist role course as well as MSN foundational courses. Students will be expected to identify the unique role of clinical nurse specialist to care outcomes, identify opportunities for consultation and collaboration, and propose or manage change at the systems level for optimal care outcomes.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Managing Community Health Issues and Systems
Description: This course will study the specific clinical nurse leader roles and responsibilities for providing clinical leadership for patient care practices and delivery, including the design, coordination, and evaluation of care for individuals, families, groups, and populations within the community/population health specialty. The focus is for students to integrate patient data and apply evidenced-based strategies for managing acute and chronic illnesses for the best patient outcomes in population health. Students are expected to participate in identification and collection of care outcomes and be accountable for evaluation and improvement of patients at the point of care. This includes risk anticipation, lateral integration of care for patients, team leadership and collaboration with other health professionals, use of information systems and technologies, and stewardship and leveraging of resources to advocate for patient in population health and community settings for point of care.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Entity Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Dutch Sustainability: Is Orange the New Green?
Description: When faced with sustainability challenges, the Dutch have always innovated their way toward a more stable and resilient environment. Through orienting reading assignments and field excursions, students learn about this country's richly varied history of cultural inclusion, land reclamation, water management, energy production, food production, and environmental preservation. These innovations have shaped Dutch society and culture in ways that earn their distinction as global leaders in redesigning their economic and infrastructure systems to meet today's sustainability challenges. Online excursion guides prepare students for visits to places throughout the Netherlands that feature old and new innovations, places of historic and cultural significance, and conversations with local experts. Course assessment is based on reflective assignments and class discussions. Students can expect to learn some Dutch in this course, but knowing Dutch is not required, since many people in the Netherlands speak some English.

Description: An intensive writing course, typically led by Calvin's writer-in-residence. Students will engage in extensive practice. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer. Students can repeat the course up to four times.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Tropical Ecosystems: Conservation and Development in Belize
Description: Tropical ecosystems contain the highest concentration of Earth's biodiversity. Under the pressures of human population growth and resource use, they are also experiencing the highest rates of biodiversity loss. How can successful conservation work occur such that the well-being of local people is not compromised or even promoted? How can human-centered development work be done in such a way that the natural ecosystem to which humans belong is not degraded? These fundamental questions will be engaged through daily field trips to a variety of tropical habitats in Belize—including coral reefs, mangrove swamps, rivers and streams, tropical rain forests, and mountain pinelands. Course participants will be hosted by local Belizean institutions, scientists, and private citizens involved in conservation and sustainability efforts. Course evaluation: daily journal, active participation in course activities and evening discussions, one written test. In preparation, students will attend three two-hour sessions during the fall semester and complete some assigned readings.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Entity Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Who Am I? Helping Professionals Grow Self-Awareness Abroad
Description: This course will focus on gaining a deeper understanding of oneself within a cross-cultural context in Puerto Rico. It will be especially relevant for those entering the helping professions, where it's imperative to know oneself in order to care well for others and to engage in healthy and sustainable ways in God's kingdom work. The purpose is to help students with self-reflection within a cross-cultural context. The learning will be accomplished through readings, guest lecturers, personality assessments, personal intercultural development plans, group processing and discussions, journaling and engagement in cross-cultural activities, and experiences in both rural and urban settings.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Hispanic Culture in the United States
Description: A study of the history and culture of Hispanic groups in the United States, their political, social, and religious institutions, and their value systems. The course is designed to assist students in understanding the cultural contributions of Hispanics within the broader US culture. Reading materials include literary and nonliterary sources.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: The World of d-Orbitals
Description: The d-orbitals dominate the chemistry of the transition metals. Though limited in abundance, these elements with their special electronic structure can be found all over the planet and used in nature and by humans to do everything from catalyzing functional reactions to forming exquisite structures. Students in this course will go deeper into various aspects of metal chemistry. Areas for exploration are supramolecular chemistry, coordination chemistry, organometallic chemistry, materials science, and metals in biological systems and processes.

Name: The World of d-Orbitals Lab
Description: In this lab, students will study systems that include metal ions using (bio)synthetic, spectroscopic, and computational methods. These experiments will prepare students to make and characterize the wide variety of molecules and materials that include transition metals.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Molecules in the Spotlight: Nanoparticles
Description: This course will introduce students to nanomaterials with a special focus on the synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles. Various applications of nanoparticles from cosmetics to targeted drug delivery in medicine to their potential toxicity will be introduced. A particular focus will be placed on understanding instrumental methods used to characterize the physical and chemical properties of nanoparticles with a special emphasis on using a UV-Vis spectrophotometer.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Molecules in the Spotlight Lab
Description: In this lab, students will perform hands-on experiments with the synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles. Analysis of the nanoparticles will be accomplished with various approaches, starting with UV-Vis spectroscopy. Students will explore the various components of a single-beam and dual-beam UV spectrometer and monitor the catalytic activity of nanoparticles by time-resolved UV-vis spectroscopy. Students will use additional instrumental techniques (FTIR, MP-AES, XRF) and visualization techniques (Atomic Force Microscopy, Image Analysis) to further characterize nanoparticles.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Chemistry and Sustainability: Life Cycle of an Electric Car
Description: Industrial chemistry shapes our lives and impacts the environment in many substantial ways. Along with the amazing advances that result from materials technology, many processes also negatively impact the environment. This course will address selected topics from areas of chemistry that impact our climate, our habitat, and human health. Emphasis will be on the chemistry and thermodynamics of these processes with a focus not only on the production but also on the deconstruction to assess the overall sustainability of a marquee example: the electric car.

Name: Chemistry and Sustainability Lab
Description: In this lab, students will conduct experiments related to battery chemistry and electrochemical processes. Students will also explore aspects of sustainability, including atmospheric impacts, minimizing mining and maximizing recycling, to understand the environmental impact of technologies and how they may be made more sustainable.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: The Quantum World
Description: An understanding of the fundamentals of quantum mechanics is valuable for every chemistry and biochemistry student. Exploring foundational questions, this course emphasizes solving the Schrödinger equation to understand the ultimate sources of microscopic modes of motion, including translation, vibration, rotation, as well as electronic transitions. Students will cultivate an understanding of quantum chemistry, equipping them to unravel the intricacies of chemical bonding and molecular spectroscopy. This course opens the door to the mysteries of quantum phenomena and provides a platform for continued studies in chemistry, physics, or related fields.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: The Quantum World Lab
Description: This lab offers a practical and hands-on approach to exploring experimental and computational applications of quantum chemistry, including molecular spectroscopy, electronic structure calculations, and the utilization of lasers in various experiments. Through these hands-on activities, students will gain experience in applying quantum chemical principles to real-world scenarios, preparing them for future studies and careers in the chemical and physical sciences.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Evolving Complexity
Description: How do you create increasingly large and complex molecules? Central to answering this question is the ability to control a reaction's mechanism, product distribution, or material properties. This course will focus on the synthesis of complicated molecules. Synthesis encompasses a variety of strategies, such as total synthesis, biosynthesis, and polymeric synthesis. Special attention will be paid to asymmetric control of traditional organic reactions, particularly using catalytic methods, as well as the growing application of catalysis and synthetic methods for the generation of high-performance polymers.

Special attention will be paid to asymmetric control of traditional organic reactions, particularly using catalytic methods, as well as the growing application of catalysis and synthetic methods for the generation of high-performance polymers.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Evolving Complexity Lab
Description: In this lab, students will complete sequential, multi-step syntheses based on procedures found in the literature. All compounds prepared will be characterized using spectroscopic methods and other instrumental techniques. Organometallic catalysts will be made and evaluated for their application to complex connections and chiral induction. Special attention will be paid to the synthesis and use of polymers in complex transformations.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Forensics and Toxicology
Description: Chemistry and chemical techniques play a pivotal role in the disciplines of forensic science and toxicology. In this course, students will learn how to apply presumptive and confirmatory tests for specific applications in forensic science. Students will then explore the chemistry of poisons at the trace element and molecular level, and the chemical and biochemical mechanisms of toxicity.

Name: Forensics and Toxicology Lab
Description: In this lab, students will learn to differentiate between presumptive and confirmatory forensic tests. Students will engage in hands-on activities using GC-MS, FTIR, and X-ray fluorescence to analyze toxic substances and fibers. Advanced instrumental approaches and simulations will also be used to study poison-receptor binding and binding effects.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Proteins Gone Awry
Description: Proteins play a multitude of roles in cell structure and function. To understand these roles, this class will go deeper into how the unique three-dimensional structures of proteins arise and influence their roles in catalysis, regulation, recognition, and information storage. Special attention will be paid to protein mutations. Students will develop an enhanced structural, thermodynamic, and dynamic understanding of biomacromolecules and their biological functions. Students will also explore how alternations in structure confer new biological properties on proteins.

Name: Proteins Gone Awry Lab

The impact of environmental changes will be assessed by measuring properties such as protein folding or enzyme kinetics. Computational modeling will also be used to better visualize macromolecules and key elements of their stability and regulation.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Venom
Description: Living cells and organisms must respond to their environment, which allows them to adapt to a variety of external conditions. We will use the language of chemistry (thermodynamics, kinetics, analysis, reactivity, and modeling) to explore systems of interactions and regulations within and between cells. Students will learn how signaling and regulation within complex biological systems leads to biological function, behavior, homeostasis, adaptation, and the emergence of new traits. We will then use these tools to examine the biochemistry of how animals, insects, plants, and microbes employ toxins to disrupt signaling pathways as a means of defense or attack.

Name: Metabolism and Metabolic Disease
Description: Metabolism is the set of chemical reactions that occur in living organisms to produce energy and the molecules that are necessary to sustain life. This course will explore cellular metabolism with a focus on the relationships between key metabolic pathways and human diseases. The primary goal of this course is to explore the ways in which chemical principles play fundamental roles in biological systems and how changes to these systems contribute to disease phenotypes.

Name: Teaching General Music
Description: Introduces music education majors to current methods and materials for teaching general music in schools. Students will gain knowledge of music curricula, pedagogy, classroom instruments, and classroom technology for teaching. All of these areas are examined through the lens of a Reformed Christian perspective.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Advanced Human Anatomy Lab
Description: This laboratory course involves a detailed study of human gross anatomy that builds on prior anatomical knowledge from other courses. Students will work in small teams to perform guided dissections of human cadavers to study tissues, organs, and organ systems. Particular attention will be paid to typical anatomical configurations, but with discussion of anatomical variants, pathological conditions, age-related changes, and clinical applications when possible. Areas of focus will include articulations, muscles, neural pathways, vasculature, and organs of the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavities.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Strategic Sports Communication
Description: This course covers the fundamentals of sports communication theory, research, and practice, enabling students to communicate well in a variety of sports environments. The course covers organizational and leadership communication in sports, sports and mass media and social media, sports and public relations and crisis communication, and sports communication and society. The course also teaches ethical and legal issues in sports communication practice. The final project involves creating an effective media or social media presence for a sports team.

School/College Name: Global Campus
Name: Wayfinder 1
Description: An introduction to how disciplines in the humanities—art and music, history, philosophy, literature, and writing—invite us to a deeper understanding of human flourishing. The two interdiscplinary coursese are taken in sequence over a full year and are unified by themes such as vocation, citizenship, diversity, and justice. This course introduces students to the features of disciplinary study in the humanities. Course themes may vary across sequences; students may take a sequence more than once but not on the same theme.

These tools and insights will be applied to scene acting, a staged monologue, a self-recorded audition, and a filmed scene in tandem with the Video Production Department and/or a New Media scene (e.g., TikTok, Instagram, Youtube, etc.).

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Water, Water, Water
Description: There are many ways to understand water: it is a substance that can be studied chemically, it is a resource that can be studied politically and economically, and it is a symbol that can be studied philosophically. Students will learn about the chemical nature of water and how its molecular structure determines its ability to host so many important chemical reactions and processes. Throughout the course, students will also learn about the availability and right to water for all humans as they rely on water for survival, enjoyment, and significance.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Congregations and the Common Good
Description: This course engages students in the study of human social activity through the lens of the church as a societal institution in the North American context. It draws together both a theology and a sociology of the church and culminates in a congregational study project in which student practice analyzing and understanding the social dynamics of the church through social science investigation.

School/College Name: School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
Name: Native American History
Description: This course explores regional Native American chiefdoms and states in the centuries before European contact; the impact of horses on the Great Plains; trade between Europeans and Americans; Christian missions in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries; the "Indian Wars" in the American West, 1840s–1890s; efforts to assimilate Native Americans in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries; and campaigns by Native Americans to promote their civil rights and tribal sovereignty in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. The course is national in scope, but focuses especially on the American West, with comparisons to indigenous peoples throughout the Americas, Africa, and Australia.

School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Prompte: Honors Capstone
Description: Taking for its title one of Calvin's key intellectual virtues, this course will serve as a capstone for the Honors Scholars Program, emphasizing prompte as a disposition of earnest commitment. At the close of students' Calvin experience, the course will bring together key themes of the Honors program: interdisciplinarity, intellectual virtues such as humility and risk-taking, habits of life-long learning, and vocational discernment. Students will explain the outcomes of their theses or creative projects for a general audience, connecting their work to real-world stakes of why such work matters.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Individual Emergency and Incident Response
Description: This medically based course is an introduction to knowledge, skills, strategies, and current best practices associated with preventing, responding, and managing incidents that require basic first aid, patient care, and communication with/transitioning to advanced medical care. Students will gain training in the Patient Assessment System, certification in CPR, and employment of AEDs. Environmental and outdoor medical situations will be covered. This experiential course will primarily utilize in-class demonstration, guided rehearsal, skills practice, and scenario-based learning. The course will also utilize weekly readings, videos, quizzes, and presentations. Students will be formally assessed through a scenario-based practical assessment and through a written exam.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Community Emergency and Incident Response
Description: This medically based course is an introduction to knowledge, skills, strategies, and current best practices associated with preventing, responding, and managing emergency situations within groups and communities. Students will learn the roles and responsibilities of individuals and teams who respond to fires, hazardous materials, terrorists, active shooters, communicable diseases, weather-related emergencies, and earthquakes. Government and non-government-based response teams will be reviewed. Students will learn how communities can utilize houses of worship, congregations, and staff members to prepare for and respond to emergencies. This experiential course will primarily utilize in-class demonstration, guided rehearsal, skills practice, and scenario-based learning. The course will also utilize weekly readings, videos, quizzes, and presentations. Students will be formally assessed through a scenario-based practical assessment and through a written exam.

School/College Name: School of Education
Name: Teaching and Christian Community
Description: This course will examine how Christian thinking about interdependent community can inform pedagogical designs and processes with a focus on the relational fabric constructed during learning and in the practices of schools. Students will examine biblical, confessional, theological, and educational sources on the nature of community and explore connections to educational practices before engaging in their own design process with explicit attention to its enactment of relational patterns.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Leadership: Service, Influence, and Transformation II
Description: This course provides students with an overview of authentic and servant leadership. The focus is on providing the critical skills of self-leadership toward personal and professional goals as the context for studying service, influence, and intentional development and growth. Students learn about individual differences and about themselves using assessment materials, analytical tools, and theory and will develop plans that support sustained growth toward personal objectives. Students are guided in a personal vision process and learn through case studies of authentic and servant leadership.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Innovation and Organizations I
Description: This course provides students with an overview and awareness of how successful organizations are able to navigate times of high uncertainty and to proactively "design for change." Focus is on students gaining the knowledge of the environment, culture, and processes needed to design for innovation and resiliency. Students also learn about individual differences and about themselves and the part they can play in their organization being one designed for innovation and resiliency in uncertain times.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Innovation and Organizations II
Description: This course builds on the cohort experience and the innovation strategy coursework by helping students think through how they will personally move forward in cultivating innovation and resiliency in their organization. Students further develop their "innovation persona" and make a connection to how it can be applied in their organization. Students gain an understanding of the soft skills needed to cultivate innovation and resiliency in their organization.

Name: Innovation Topics
Description: This course is a topics course, which features a different business innovation strategy topic each time it is offered. Possible topics include disruptive innovation, human-centered design, innovation case studies, and other "timeless" topics, as well as current hot topics.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Marketing Strategy
Description: This course introduces the strategic marketing management process to prepare students to be successful marketing managers by learning to craft and execute marketing strategies that contribute to organizational success. Students take a deeper dive into strategic areas of competitive market analysis, segmentation, branding, distribution channels, pricing, and integrated marketing communication. The course uses both a textbook and cases and focuses on applying concepts into practice. In addition, students are challenged to critically evaluate the above from a Christian perspective.

School/College Name: School of Business
Name: Advanced Corporate Finance
Description: This course covers four topics from the perspective of a corporate or nonprofit chief financial officer: mergers and acquisition, private equity, credit markets, and derivatives. Students gain an understanding of the relevant frameworks, the ability to perform financial analysis on each topic, and learn how to apply them to actual companies.

School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Honors Creative Writing
Description: Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will emphasize creative writing (whether nonfiction, fiction, or poetry) as a form of problem-solving, embedded within larger social contexts. Particular attention will be paid to genre conventions and audience expectations. The interdisciplinary component will attend to how writing not only expresses ideas but gives shape to them along the way.
