School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Honors Rhetoric
Description: Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will address communication practices as problem-solving forms embedded within social contexts. While topics will vary from year to year, all iterations will pay particular attention to the modes—that is, the styles or postures—that circulate across the attention economies of modern societies, from digital platforms to everyday physical spaces. The interdisciplinary component will attend to how communication practices and modes are structured by conversations in other disciplines.

School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Honors Visual Art
Description: Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will address works of visual art with the goal of developing two skills as tied to problem solving: effective observation of artistic production and explanation of how specific works of art shape one's place within a larger community. From year to year, the visual material will vary by media and historical periods and may include studio production. Appropriate methodological tools will be used to explore visual expression as an encounter between makers and viewers. The interdisciplinary component will attend to that expression as structured by conversations in other disciplines.

School/College Name: School of Health
Name: Fundamentals of Patient Care
Description: This class reviews the basics of patient caregiving and will prepare learners to take the CNA certification test if desired. This intensive course will consist of a minimum of 75 hours of combined classroom, laboratory, and clinical hours. Relational competencies along with the clinical skills mastered will develop skilled providers of personal care in a geriatric setting. The classroom instruction taught from a Reformed perspective will be integrated with a minimum of 16 hours of direct patient care during the clinical time at Holland Home.

School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Community in a Costa Rican Watershed
Description: An on-site seminar that provides orientation to Costa Rican culture and introduces students to various cross-cultural issues. Furthermore, this course aims to help students engage with the local neighborhood association to help restore the vitality of the Virilla River and watershed. Students discuss and reflect on what they learn from readings, interviews, and daily experiences. Includes guest speakers and excursions. This course is required of all students who participate in the abroad program.

School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Cohorts Intensive: Sustainability Fellows Travel
Description: A foundational experience of the Sustainability Fellows cohort, this off-campus travel course will introduce students to and deepen engagement in sustainability in diverse contexts. The course will be interdisciplinary in focus but may pair with another course in the cohort progression to complement its content. Travel location and specific course topic will be announced approximately one year in advance. Enrolled students should plan on traveling over fall break, Winter Intensive, spring break, or summer, depending on the course topic offered. Travel costs will be paid by Calvin Cohorts.

Description: A culminating experience of the Arts Collective, this off-campus travel course will introduce students to and deepen engagement in the arts in a particular context. The course will be interdisciplinary in focus but may pair with another course in the cohort progression to complement its content. Travel location and specific course topic will be announced approximately one year in advance. Enrolled students should plan on traveling over fall break, Winter Intensive, spring break, or summer, depending on the course topic offered. Travel costs will be paid for by Calvin Cohorts.

School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Cohorts Intensive: Common Good Collective Travel
Description: This off-campus travel course will be a culminating experience for students in the Common Good Collective to examine concepts of place and the common good. The course will be interdisciplinary in focus but may pair with another course in the cohort progression to complement its content. Completion of this course will fulfill the Diversity and Difference (tag) requirement in the Calvin Core. Travel location and specific course topic will be announced approximately one year in advance. Enrolled students should plan on traveling over fall break, Winter Intensive, spring break, or summer, depending on the course topic offered. Travel costs will be paid by Calvin Cohorts.

School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Sustainability Action Workshop
Description: In this course, students will work in small groups, paired with a community organization, to address a sustainability-related challenge. In addition to this real-world project work, students will meet weekly to share progress, brainstorm solutions, and gain practical sustainability leadership and action skills.

School/College Name: School of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Name: Contemporary Topics in Biology
Description: This course addresses a variety of advanced topics that are important in contemporary biological disciplines (e.g., detailed study of specific taxonomic groups, emerging fields of biological inquiry, and more). Lectures, discussions, readings, and laboratory/field studies provide students with advanced conceptual knowledge and practical experiences that develop important vocational skills. Course work centers around scientific literature, investigation, and communication.

School/College Name: Calvin University
Name: Honors Community and Commitments
Description: As a point of entry for both Calvin's Core curriculum and the Honors Scholars program, this course introduces the institutional project of thinking deeply, with eyes always toward justice and renewal. Taught alongside a second course in the Calvin Core, this course emphasizes Calvin's Reformed theological foundations and its attendant commitments to justice, intercultural learning, and sustainability through the lens of a particular discipline.
